messageBody:
These two should definitely make it into the FAQ!
 
To answer "how to test an abstract class," here's a combination of two messages that jphedley@... and I sent out a few weeks back (thanks J.!):
 
1) Class declared abstract but with no abstract methods.  As an inner class to my testing class, I made a concrete extension the abstract super class which I use for testing purposes.  For example in AbstractFooTest, I created an inner class, AbstractFooExtension, which extends AbstractFoo.

2) Class with abstract methods on which the concrete methods have no dependencies.  Same as 1) but stub in the abstract methods.  In other words, if the abstract methods can't impact state or are not called by the concrete methods, then I am free to test concrete methods.

3) Class with abstract methods on which the concrete methods do have dependencies.  Simply mimic your class hierarchy in your test classes.  For example, to test an abstract "AbstractNavigator" class, write an "AbstractNavigatorTest" class--also abstract.  You can write all the test cases here that should apply to any type of navigator.  And add an abstract method to it such as:

    public asbstract AbstractNavigator newTestInstance();

Now, to test one of the concrete implementations (which I assume you plan to do! :-)), just write a test class as a subclass of AbstractNavigatorTest--mirroring the production code's inheritance hierarchy.  Implement that newTestInstance() method to return a new instance of the implementing class you're testing, and you should be good to go.
 
Kevin
